Graphical abstract By tuning the Pr/Sr ratio and NiCl2 etching, we construct a catalyst with Pr-stabilized perovskite core@NiFe hydroxide shell for dual-function catalysis. The bifunctional oxygen evolution/reduction reaction (OER/ORR) performance of perovskite oxides in zinc-air batteries (ZABs) is fundamentally constrained by the unidirectional catalytic activity of B-site transition metal elements. This work proposes a heterostructure engineering strategy through selective etching to construct crystalline perovskite@amorphous hydroxide composites with spatially segregated active sites, where crystalline cores are for ORR and amorphous shells are for OER. Our investigation reveals that the differential solubility of alkaline-earth and rare-earth elements in acidic media enables precise control over surface amorphous layer composition and thickness through A-site cation ratio modulation and tailored etching protocols. Ab initio molecular dynamics (AIMD) simulations reveal the coupled process of A-site cations dissolution, oxygen vacancy formation, and amorphous-layer growth during the dynamic restructuring of the core-shell structure. The optimized Pr0.25Sr0.75FeO3− δ @NiFe LDH achieved a 212 mV improvement of OER/ORR potential gap (ΔE = E 10 mA cm−2 − E 1/2) over pristine Pr0.25Sr0.75FeO3− δ . When deployed in ZABs, the catalyst demonstrates a peak power density of 92.9 mW cm−2 and exceptional cycling stability with only 6.3% energy efficiency decay after 300 h (vs. 10.2% decay for Pt/C-RuO2). This work establishes a universal “composition-guided reconstruction” paradigm, providing both theoretical insights and practical solutions for high-performance electrode design of ZABs. Keywords Perovskite oxide Bifunctional catalyst Rechargeable zinc-air batteries 1 Introduction Zinc-air batteries (ZABs), with high theoretical energy density, low cost, and environmental friendliness, are regarded as promising candidates for next-generation renewable energy storage and conversion systems [1]. However, their practical applications are hindered by sluggish oxygen evolution/reduction reaction (OER/ORR) kinetics at the air cathode, making the development of highly active and durable bifunctional electrocatalysts a critical challenge in this field. To date, noble metal-based materials such as RuO2, IrO2, and Pt/C still exhibit the highest catalytic activity for either OER or ORR [2–6]. Nevertheless, their prohibitive cost, poor bifunctional performance, and insufficient stability severely limit further large-scale applications. Perovskite oxides (ABO3), owing to their tunable electronic structures, abundant oxygen vacancy concentrations, and excellent redox stability, have emerged as ideal alternatives to noble metal catalysts [7–13]. In principle, precise regulation of their A/B-site elemental compositions and crystal structures could synchronously optimize OER/ORR bifunctional activities. However, the intrinsic catalytic preferences of B-site transition metals often lead to incompatible optimization of dual functionalities. For instance, Lv et al. demonstrated that Mn3+ doping in Pr0.6Sr0.4Fe1− x Mn x O3− δ optimizes the ORR pathway toward a four-electron transfer process but concurrently increases the OER overpotential significantly [14]. Similarly, David et al. systematically investigated the LaMn1− x Ni x O3− δ system and found that increasing Ni doping levels linearly enhanced OER activity, while the half-wave potential of ORR gradually shifted negatively, revealing an inherent antagonistic effect between bifunctional activities [15]. Perovskite-based heterostructures are considered a promising strategy to overcome the limitations of bifunctional electrocatalytic activity [16]. However, conventional mechanical compositing methods, such as mixing with carbon materials, suffer from drawbacks including weak interfacial bonding, component segregation during OER possess, and increased interfacial resistance [17]. In-situ formation of carbon-based composites often requires high-temperature annealing (>600 °C), leading to perovskite surface amorphization and elemental segregation, thus severely compromising structural stability [18–20]. Therefore, the in-situ construction of high-density OER and ORR dual active sites within a single perovskite system while maintaining the stability of the heterostructure interface poses a significant challenge in advancing the design of bifunctional catalysts [21]. Recent studies reveal that reconstructed hydroxyl oxides on perovskite surfaces exhibit exceptional OER activity [22–26]. For instance, He et al. demonstrated that surface F− doping induces in situ reconstruction of LaNi0.75Fe0.25O3− δ during OER, forming a LaNi0.75Fe0.25O3− δ /NiFeOOH heterostructure that reduces OER overpotential by 292 mV at 10 mA cm−2 [27]. Wang et al. indicated that A-site Ce3+ doping in LaNiO3− δ lowers oxygen vacancy formation energy, accelerating NiOOH reconstruction kinetics [28]. Xue et al. identified that perovskites undergo spontaneous surface reconstruction in alkaline media abiding by lattice oxygen evolution mechanism (LOM), with prolonged 1 M KOH immersion facilitating amorphous CoOOH layer formation on SrCoO3− δ [29]. Despite these advances, a critical trade-off persists. While surface reconstruction driven by A-site cation dissolution (e.g., Sr2+, La3+) and oxygen vacancy generation enhances OER activity through active hydroxyl oxide formation, excessive ion leaching destabilizes perovskite crystallinity, inducing lattice collapse and reducing bulk utilization [30,31]. Moreover, dissolved A-site cations (e.g., La3+) readily combine with OH− to form insulating La(OH)3 passivation layers that mask B-site active centers, severely degrading ORR activity and cycling stability [32]. This inherent contradiction renders conventional perovskites incapable of reconciling ORR/OER bifunctionality, significantly limiting their practical applications. To address these challenges, we propose a novel strategy involving selective etching of A-site cations to construct perovskite@hydroxide core-shell architectures, enabling spatial decoupling and synergistic integration of ORR/OER active sites. By utilizing an acidic NiCl2 solution to selectively extract alkaline-earth cations (e.g., Sr2+) while preserving rare-earth ions (e.g., Pr3+) as structural stabilizers, we successfully constructed a core-shell heterostructure with independently functioning OER and ORR zones. In this structure, the high dissolution resistance of Pr3+ maintains the integrity of the perovskite framework, preserving the ORR-active B-O6 octahedra. Meanwhile, the leaching of Sr2+ induces surface oxygen vacancy enrichment, driving the in-situ reconstruction of B-site Fe3+/Ni2+ into an amorphous NiFe layered double hydroxides (LDH) shell with enhanced OER activity. Through operando Raman spectroscopy, X-ray absorption near-edge structure spectroscopy (XANES), scanning transmission electron microscopy (TEM), and Ab initio molecular dynamics (AIMD) simulations, we elucidate the coupled mechanisms of A-site dissolution, oxygen vacancy evolution, and amorphous layer growth during dynamic reconstruction. The optimized Pr0.25Sr0.75FeO3− δ @NiFe LDH cathode delivers a peak power density of 92.9 mW cm−2 and 6.3% round-trip efficiency decay after 300-h cycling in ZABs, outperforming commercial Pt/C-RuO2 systems (10.2% round-trip efficiency decay). This work establishes a paradigm for resolving the “OER-ORR activity” trade-off in perovskite catalysts, advancing the rational design of high-performance bifunctional electrodes. 2 Results and discussion 2.1 Structure characterization As illustrated in Fig. 1 (a), a series of Sr/Pr-tunable perovskites (Pr1− x Sr x FeO3− δ , x = 0, 0.25, 0.5, 0.75, and 1; denoted as PFO, PSF-0.25, PSF-0.5, PSF-0.75, and SFO) were synthesized via self-propagating combustion synthesis. X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis reveals systematic peak shifts toward higher angles with increasing Sr2+ doping (Fig. 1a), indicative of progressive lattice contraction. Despite the larger ionic radius of Sr2+ (1.44 Å) compared to Pr3+ (1.13 Å), partial oxidation of B-site Fe3+ (0.645 Å) to smaller Fe4+ (0.585 Å) occurs to maintain charge compensation, driving overall lattice shrinkage (Fig. 1b). The Rietveld refinement results of XRD (Fig. 1b and Fig. S1) further demonstrate that the lattice parameters of the perovskite oxide gradually decrease as the Sr content increases. Moreover, the crystal structure of Pr1− x Sr x FeO3− δ gradually transitions from the orthorhombic phase (Pnma) to the higher symmetry cubic phase (Pm-3m) when the Sr content exceeds 50% (x > 0.5) [14,33,34]. NiCl2-treated perovskite oxide (labeled as PFO-Ni, PSF-0.25-Ni, etc.) exhibits distinct structural responses. While Pr1− x Sr x FeO3− δ (x ≤ 0.75) retains its perovskite main phase with minor crystallinity degradation (Fig. 1c), SFO undergoes complete phase transformation to nickel-iron layered double hydroxide (NiFe-LDH) under identical conditions. We hypothesize that this discrepancy originates from the relatively weak metal–oxygen bonds of alkaline-earth metal cations (Sr2+/Ba2+), which facilitate their preferential leaching under mildly acidic conditions, whereas the stronger Pr–O bonds in rare-earth Pr3+ effectively stabilize the framework structure of the perovskite oxide. Validation experiments on Pr0.125Sr0.875FeO3− δ (PSF-0.875) and Ba0.5Sr0.5FeO3− δ (BSF) confirm that even 12.5% Pr content in A-site sufficiently inhibits structural collapse, while BSF fully converts to NiFe-LDH due to weaker Ba–O bonding (Figs. S2, S3). Notably, comparison of the XRD spectra of PSF-0.75 before and after etching reveals that the (110) diffraction peak of etched PSF-0.75-Ni not only produces a slight decrease in crystallinity but also shifts to a higher angle (Fig. S4). This may be due to the loss of the A-position cation, which causes the B-site Fe2+/Fe3+ ion to be reduced to a higher valence state with a lower ionic radius, resulting in a compressive strain inside the crystal and a contraction of the lattice volume. To investigate the surface reconstruction mechanism, TEM characterization was performed on the PSF-0.75-Ni sample. High-resolution TEM (HRTEM) images (Fig. 1e and Fig. S5) revealed that the perovskite core, with interplanar spacings of 0.282 and 0.201 nm corresponding to the (110) and (200) planes, is covered by an approximately tens of nanometres thick amorphous layer [35]. Energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) line-scan analysis (Fig. 1h) showed that the concentration gradient of Pr and Sr increases from the surface to the bulk, while Ni is enriched in the near-surface region. The EDS mapping results further indicated that Sr elements exhibit local depletion on the surface on a scale of 10–100 nm, while Ni precisely fills the vacancies formed by Sr dissolution, resulting in a crystal perovskite@amorphous hydroxide core-shell structure (Fig. 1i). This unique structural design stabilizes the ORR active sites in the core through the rare earth element (Pr3+) while utilizing the Sr2+ vacancies to provide sufficient space for anchoring the amorphous NiFe hydroxide shell, creating an ideal active interface for bifunctional catalysis. To further investigate the mechanism by which NiCl2 solution etches A-site rare/alkaline earth perovskite oxides, this study employs EDS, Raman spectroscopy, and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) to systematically reveal the evolution of elemental distribution, crystal structure, and surface chemical states during the etching process. Quantitative EDS analysis of the elemental distribution in etched and unetched samples (Fig. 2 a–c and Figs. S6–S17) shows that for Pr-containing Pr1− x Sr x FeO3− δ -Ni (x = 0, 0.25, 0.5, 0.75, and 0.875), the Sr content decreases by approximately 50% after NiCl2 treatment, while the Pr content remains relatively stable (fluctuation <15%). In contrast, the Sr content in pure Sr-based perovskite (SFO) sharply drops to 13% of its initial value. This difference further indicates that the rare earth element Pr3+, through its strong Pr–O bonding, significantly inhibits A-site dissolution and effectively maintains the crystallographic integrity of the perovskite core during the formation process of the core-shell structure (Fig. 2c). Further analysis reveals that the Ni enrichment level in Pr1− x Sr x FeO3− δ -Ni samples is inversely correlated with the A-site Sr content, suggesting that by tuning the A-site Pr/Sr ratio, the etching depth and the thickness of the amorphous shell layer can be precisely controlled, providing critical guidance for the controllable preparation of the core-shell structure. The relationship between the Fe/Ni elemental ratio of PSF-Ni and the types and amounts of A-site elements is shown in Fig. S18. This reveals that by controlling the A-site elements in the perovskite substrate, the elemental ratio of the surface amorphous layer can be quantitatively controlled. Inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS) analysis also confirmed this, with the Fe/Ni ratios in PFO-Ni, PSF-0.75-Ni, and SFO-Ni being 4:1, 2.09:1, and 0.87:1, respectively. This is consistent with the results observed from DES mapping. The dissolved concentrations of Pr and Sr in PFO-Ni and SFO-Ni were 25.8 and 0.64 ppm, respectively, further demonstrating the stability of the rare earth element Pr during the in-situ etching process. Raman spectroscopy analysis (Fig. 2d, e) shows that the characteristic peaks of the unetched samples at 430 cm−1 (Fe–O bending vibration, Ag mode) and 670 cm−1 (Fe–O stretching vibration, B2g mode) in Pr1− x Sr x FeO3− δ decrease with increasing Sr doping concentration, confirming that the introduction of Sr2+ enhances the crystal symmetry (from orthorhombic phase to cubic phase), consistent with the Rietveld refinement results of XRD [35,36]. Additionally, the smaller ionic radius of Fe4+, induced by the charge neutrality principle, causes the Fe–O (B2g mode) band to shift to a higher wavenumber (redshift) [37]. For the etched samples, characteristic peaks at 480 and 570 cm−1 correspond to NiFe-LDH, with their intensities positively correlated with the extent of Sr loss. The significant enhancement of the Fe–O peak at 670 cm−1 is attributed to local Fe–O6 coordination distortions induced by surface oxygen vacancies, a phenomenon consistent with the reported mechanism of oxygen defects promoting the formation of amorphous phases [35,38,39]. XPS analysis (Fig. 2f, g) further reveals that for etched PFO-Ni, the proportion of surface lattice oxygen (O2−, 529.5 eV) decreases from 32.6% to 14.4%, while the proportions of adsorbed oxygen (O−/O2 2−, 531.2 eV) and hydroxyl oxygen (OH−/O2, 532.5 eV) increase from 22.4% and 30.9% to 25.3% and 42.7%, respectively [40]. This indicates that more oxygen vacancies are generated during the surface reconstruction process, accompanied by the formation of an amorphous hydroxide layer. Similarly, for PSF-0.75 and SFO, excessive Sr loss during etching, along with the formation of the amorphous hydroxide layer, makes surface lattice oxygen difficult to detect (Fig. 2g). Compared to PFO, the surface Pr elemental intensity in PFO-Ni is significantly reduced, while the Sr 3d signal in SFO-Ni disappears, directly confirming the preferential dissolution of Sr2+ and the structural stabilizing role of Pr3+ (Figs. S19, 20). As shown in Fig. 2(h), the emergence of characteristic peaks at 854.2 eV (Ni 2p 3/2) and 872.5 eV (Ni 2p 1/2), coupled with the increase in the Ni/Fe atomic ratio from 1.45 in PFO-Ni to 3.26 in PSF-0.75-Ni, demonstrates that Ni2+ selectively occupies the Sr dissolution sites, forming a dense perovskite@hydroxide core-shell heterojunction. These results indicate that by controlling the A-site Pr/Sr ratio and utilizing selective etching with NiCl2 solution, a dual-functional catalytic system with a Pr-stabilized perovskite core and a NiFe hydroxide shell can be precisely constructed. Meanwhile, we further investigated the relationship between the etching time and its surface structure and elemental composition. Raman spectra of PSF-0.25 and PSF-0.75 etched in 0.05 M NiCl2 for varying durations (0–7 h) reveal a direct correlation between etching time and the intensity of amorphous oxyhydroxide surface peaks (Fig. S21). However, under the condition of the same etching time, the content of loaded amorphous hydroxide is obviously higher for the samples with a higher proportion of Sr at the A-site, which implies that the proportion of rare earth to alkaline earth of the A-site cation has a more important role in controlling the depth of surface etching. The ICP-MS data of PSF-0.75 etched by 0.05 M NiCl2 solution for different times (0, 1, 3, 5, and 7 h) are shown in Table S1. It can be seen that during the etching for 1 h, there is a drastic loss of Sr2+ ions and simultaneous deposition of nickel ions. During the next etching for 3, 5, and 7 h, the etching rate of Pr3+ and Sr2+ ions and the deposition rate of Ni2+ ions are relatively uniform, which indicates that the etching time plays an important role in controlling the content of the surface amorphous layer. Moreover, the mass ratio loss of Pr3+ is much lower than that of Sr2+ in different etching time ranges, which further demonstrates the role of Pr3+ ions in stabilizing the crystal structure of perovskite oxide. 2.2 Electrocatalytic performance The OER/ORR bifunctional activities of the perovskite oxide were systematically evaluated using rotating disk electrode (RDE) measurements in 0.1 M KOH (all potentials referenced to the reversible hydrogen electrode). As shown in Fig. 3 (a) and Fig. S22, core-shell catalysts exhibited enhanced ORR activity compared to pristine perovskites, with PSF-0.75-Ni demonstrating a 76 mV positive shift in half-wave potential (E 1/2 = 0.605 V vs. RHE) relative to PSF-0.75 (E 1/2 = 0.529 V). Based on the Koutecký-Levich (K-L) equation fitting of the rotation-dependent linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) curves (400–2500 r min−1), the electron transfer numbers (n) for the various catalysts were calculated as follows: PFO (2.2), PSF-0.75 (2.3), SFO (2.4), PFO-Ni (2.3), PSF-0.75-Ni (2.5), and SFO-Ni (2.3). These results demonstrate that the amorphous NiFe-LDH shell does not alter the ORR electronic reaction pathway of the perovskite core. For OER performance, core-shell catalysts demonstrated remarkable advantages (Fig. 3c, d). PSF-0.75-Ni achieved an overpotential of 281 mV at 10 mA cm−2, outperforming both PSF-0.75 (417 mV) and commercial RuO2 (401 mV). Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) recorded at 1.55 vs. RHE (Fig. 3e, f) reveals that PSF-0.75-Ni exhibits the lowest polarization resistance among the catalysts, signifying faster charge transfer during the OER reaction. Tafel plots and corresponding fitting data for different catalyst samples are shown in Fig. 3(g, h) and Fig. S23. The lower Tafel value of 70.4 mV dec−1 for PSF-0.75-Ni, compared to 81 mV dec−1 for PSF-0.75, indicates enhanced OER kinetics. By evaluating the double-layer capacitance (C dl), the electrochemically active surface area (ECSA) was assessed, showing that the C dl of Pr1− x Sr x FeO3− δ increases with Sr content (x) and reaches a maximum of 4.01 mF cm−2 at x = 0.75 (Fig. 3i, Fig. S24). Normalized current density analysis reveals that the current densities of Pr1− x Sr x FeO3− δ at an overpotential of 400 mV are 0.11, 0.12, 0.11, and 0.11 mA cm−2, respectively, indicating that Sr doping enhances OER activity by increasing the density of active sites. However, the C dl values for Pr1− x Sr x FeO3− δ -Ni (x < 1) are significantly reduced and approach 1 mF cm−2, confirming that the OER active sites shift from the Fe ions at the B-site of the perovskite to the amorphous NiFe-LDH shell (Fig. S25). Normalized current density analysis further demonstrates that the intrinsic activity of PSF-0.75-Ni at 300 mV overpotential (1.08 mA cm−2) is approximately 140 times higher than that of PSF-0.75 (0.008 mA cm−2), highlighting the efficient catalytic role of the amorphous shell (Fig. S26). The OER stability of PSF-0.75-Ni was tested using a foam nickel-loaded electrode (Fig. 3j). Its initial overpotential (281 mV) is consistent with the RDE test results, and after 1000 cycle voltage (CV) cycles, the overpotential decreases further to 264 mV (Fig. S27). Additionally, to further demonstrate the advantage of OER stability of the etched samples, we employed carbon paper as a load to avoid the effect of sample detachment during the high-speed rotation of RDE and examined the cyclic stability of PSF-0.75 and PSF-0.75-Ni in 1 M KOH solution. As seen in Fig. S28, the OER overpotentials of PSF and PSF-0.75-Ni in 1 M KOH solution further decreased to 303 and 236 mV. As seen, the overpotentials of PSF-0.75 after 5000 cycles of the CV test increased by 150 mV, whereas the overpotentials of PSF-0.75-Ni after 10,000 cycles of the CV test only increased by 16 mV, which further demonstrates the significant advantage of amorphous shell layer construction in OER stability enhancement. Furthermore, a 100-h chrono-potentiometric test shows negligible overpotential increase (<5 mV). XRD characterization (Fig. S29) reveals that the sample retains its perovskite phase after cycling, with only a slight reduction in crystallinity, demonstrating the excellent mechanical and chemical stability of the core-shell structure. The scanning electron microscope (SEM) images of PSF-0.75-Ni before and after the OER test are shown in Fig. S30. Compared with the initial samples, PSF-0.75-Ni still maintains irregular particles, and the size stays around a few hundred nanometres with almost no change after the OER stability test. Furthermore, we recorded the ICP-MS data of PSF-0.75 and PSF-0.75-Ni before and after the OER stability test. We can find that after the OER stability test, the Pr, Sr, and Fe mass ratios of PSF-0.75 are 96.7%, 90.8%, and 90.7% of those before the test, respectively. In contrast, the mass ratios of Pr, Sr, Fe, and Ni for PSF-0.75 were 97%, 95.4%, 95.2%, and 97.5% of the initial mass ratios after the OER stability test, respectively. This further demonstrates that the materials constructed using surface amorphous hydroxides have a more stable structure during the OER process. To validate the necessity of in situ constructing the core-shell structure, a mechanical mixture of PSF-0.75 and NiFe LDH (PSF-0.75/NiFe LDH) was prepared (Fig. S31). As shown in Fig. S32, the ORR half-wave potential of the mixture (0.582 V) is higher than that of PSF-0.75 (0.529 V), but still lower than that of PSF-0.75-Ni (0.605 V). Similarly, the OER overpotential of the mixture (316 mV) is inferior to that of PSF-0.75-Ni (281 mV). The electron transfer number of the mixture (PSF-0.75/NiFe LDH: 2.86) is close to that of pure NiFe-LDH (2.3), confirming that both the mechanical mixture and the in situ core-shell structure do not alter the ORR electron transfer mechanism of the perovskite oxide. The lowest polarization resistance of PSF-0.75-Ni, as shown in Fig. S33, further confirms its optimized interfacial charge transfer properties. Additionally, the Tafel slope (Fig. S34) of PSF-0.75-Ni (70.4 mV dec−1) is significantly lower than that of the mechanical mixture (113.3 mV dec−1) and pure NiFe-LDH (95.7 mV dec−1). Furthermore, we prepared NiFe-LDH supported on PSF-0.75 via co-precipitation (denoted PSF-0.75-NiFe LDH) at a 1:1 mass ratio. As shown in Fig. S35, PSF-0.75-NiFe LDH exhibits an OER overpotential of 308 mV at 10 mA cm−2, 27 mV higher than PSF-0.75-Ni (281 mV). This difference validates the superior catalytic efficiency achieved through in situ etching in NiCl2 solution compared to hydroxide loading. In order to clarify the unique advantages of NiCl2 solution etching in terms of OER performance enhancement, we prepared the PSF-0.75 etched with 0.05 M FeCl3 solution, 0.05 M CoCl2 solution, and HCl solution with the same pH as 0.05 M NiCl2 solution, which are named PSF-0.75-Fe, PSF-0.75-Co, and PSF-0.75-H in that order. Due to the high hydrolysis capacity of FeCl3, causing rapid decomposition under strong acidity, PSF-0.75-Fe was prepared via room-temperature immersion to mitigate its etching. Except for PSF-0.75-Fe, the etching process of the rest of the solutions was identical to that of PSF-0.75-Ni. As seen in Fig. S36, not all acidic solution etching acted as an enhancement of the OER catalytic activity of perovskite oxides. The overpotentials at the current density of 10 mA cm−2 of different samples follow the order of PSF-0.75-Fe (487 mV) > PSF-0.75-H (451 mV) > PSF-0.75 (417 mV) > PSF-0.75-Co (350 mV) > PSF-0.75-Ni (281 mV), which further proves the unique advantage of NiCl2 solution etching in enhancing the OER catalytic activity of samples. As shown in Fig. S36(b), the onset potential, half-wave potential, and limiting current density of PSF-0.75 etched by FeCl3 solution and HCl solution were decreased. However, NiCl2 and CoCl2 solution etching promoted its ORR activity. Interestingly, the current density of PSF-0.75-Co in the diffusion region was significantly increased by CoCl2 solution etching, which implied that it might have changed the electron path of PSF-0.75. To clarify the dominant roles of the perovskite oxide and the amorphous hydroxide in the OER/ORR catalytic reactions within the core-shell structure, the method was extended to perovskite systems with different B-site metals (PMO: PrMnO3− δ and PCO: PrCoO3− δ ) (Fig. S37). As shown in Fig. 4 (a, b), the XRD and Raman spectra of PMO-Ni and PCO-Ni after NiCl2 treatment retain the perovskite main phase, with only weak hydroxide characteristic peaks appearing in the 400–600 cm−1 region. ORR performance tests (Fig. 4c and Fig. S38) show that the amorphous hydroxide is more effective in improving the catalytic activity of iron-based perovskite oxides. The electron transfer numbers of PMO-Ni (n = 4.35), PCO-Ni (n = 3.8), and their respective pristine perovskites (PMO: n = 4.09, PCO: n = 3.8) remain largely unchanged, confirming that the amorphous shell does not interfere with the ORR pathway. In order to solve the problem of n exceeding 4 and to make our data more rigorous, the H2O2 production rate and electron transfer number are measured by the rotating ring disc electrodes (RRDE). As shown in Fig. S39, PMO and PMO-Ni exhibit a significantly lower H2O2 yield and a higher number of electrons transferred when compared to other samples. The electron transfer numbers of various samples calculated from RRDE and the K-L equation at 0.4 V vs. RHE are compared in Table S2. We can observe that all n of the different samples are lower than 4, and the trend of electron transfer numbers measured by RRDE across various samples fundamentally aligns with the values calculated via the K-L equation. The OER overpotentials are reduced by 178 mV (PMO-Ni: 453 mV vs. PMO: 631 mV) and 9 mV (PCO-Ni: 386 mV vs. PCO: 435 mV). Notably, the Fe-based system (PFO-Ni) exhibits the best OER activity (overpotential of 320 mV), indicating that Fe-ion-doped NiFe LDH has a higher intrinsic activity for OER catalysis. These results further confirm that the amorphous hydroxide and crystalline perovskite in the core-shell structure dominantly catalyze OER and ORR, respectively. Additionally, we evaluated the ORR and OER cycling stability of perovskite oxides with varying transition metals at the B-site. Fig. S40 reveals that the heterogeneous structure formed by the in situ amorphous hydroxide shell did not substantially enhance ORR stability. The ORR polarisation curves of the different samples after 500 and 1000 cycles of CV testing showed a similar decaying trend to that of the unetched samples. When it comes to the OER stability, the overpotentials at the current density of 10 mA cm−2 of PFO, PCO, and PMO increased by 153, 49, and 195 mV after the 500-cycle CV test, respectively. However, the OER overpotentials of the etched samples showed a negligible increase after the 1000-cycle CV test (Fig. S41). This further demonstrates the universality of amorphous shell layer structures built on the surfaces of different types of perovskite oxides in enhancing the stability of OER. To verify the universality of this strategy, typical perovskite systems reported in the literature (PSFM: Pr0.6Sr0.4Fe0.5Mn0.5O3− δ , PSFC: Pr0.25Sr0.75Fe0.5Co0.5O3− δ , and PSFN: Pr0.25Sr0.75Fe0.9Ni0.1O3− δ ) were selected for comparative experiments. Using the same NiCl2 solution etching process, crystalline perovskite@amorphous hydroxide core-shell structures were successfully constructed (Fig. 4c, d and Fig. S42). The half-wave potentials of etched B-site doped perovskite oxides are significantly improved. For example, the half-wave potential of PSFM-Ni (E 1/2 = 0.648 V vs. RHE) is 25 mV higher than that of the undoped pristine PSFM (0.623 V), and its electron transfer number (n = 4.35) approaches the theoretical value for a four-electron pathway, demonstrating the best ORR activity. In terms of OER, PSFC-Ni exhibits the best OER activity, with an overpotential of 278 mV, which is 74 mV lower than that of PSFC (352 mV). Its Tafel slope (57.9 mV dec−1) is significantly lower than that of the comparative samples (PSFC: 74.3 mV dec−1), demonstrating the efficient catalytic role of the amorphous shell. Additionally, comparing the bifunctional overpotentials demonstrates that PSFC-Ni shows a significant voltage difference (ΔE = 0.855 V), reducing by 330 mV compared to PFO (ΔE = 1.185 V) and by 102 mV compared to PFO-Ni (ΔE = 0.957 V). These results confirm that the “A-site tuning-in situ etching” strategy can universally construct high-performance bifunctional catalysts. 2.3 In situ Raman spectroscopic analysis Comparative analysis of the cyclic voltammetry curves in Fig. 5 (a and b) reveals that the Ni2+/Ni3+ oxidation peaks are distinctly observed in the amorphous NiFe LDH-modified catalytic system within the potential range of around 1.4–1.5 V vs. RHE, whereas no such characteristic peaks are detected in the pristine perovskite oxide system [41,42]. Notably, the oxidation peak onset potential shifts negatively (from 1.46 V of PFO-Ni to 1.38 V of SFO-Ni) as the Sr doping concentration at the A-site of the perovskite increases, suggesting the formation of NiFeOOH intermediates with enhanced OER activity within the amorphous structure. To elucidate the mechanism by which the amorphous hydroxide layer enhances catalytic activity, operando Raman spectroscopy was employed to track surface structural evolution during OER. As shown in Fig. 5(c, d) and Fig. S43, the PSF-0.75 sample lacks FeOOH vibrational signatures (300–600 cm−1) across 0.95–1.85 V vs. RHE, confirming B-site Fe ion as the intrinsic OER active center. In contrast, PSF-0.75-Ni displays progressive conversion of NiFe LDH peaks (480 cm−1 Eg bending, 555 cm−1 A1g stretching) to NiFeOOH modes under applied voltage [43]. Notably, the vibrational intensity at 680 cm−1, associated with the B2g mode of the Fe–O6 octahedron, increases as the potential rises. This increase is likely due to the formation of oxygen vacancies during the OER process, which disrupts the octahedral symmetry. To probe Fe3+-driven structural regulation of Ni-based active phases, phase-pure Ni(OH)2 was synthesized via coprecipitation (Fig. 5e). Its characteristic peaks at 470 cm−1 (Ni2+–O, Eg) and 550 cm−1 (Ni2+–O, A1g) exhibit significant blueshift upon polarization to 1.55 V, indicative of Ni2+ to Ni3+ oxidation-induced lattice contraction [44,45]. Comparative Raman analysis at 1.85 V (Fig. S44a) reveals a 3 cm−1 redshift in Eg mode for PSF-0.75-Ni versus Ni(OH)2, confirming Fe3+ incorporation into NiOOH lattices [46,47]. Lorentzian fitting of vibrational intensity ratios (I B/I S = 1.36 for PSF-0.75-Ni and 2.56 for Ni(OH)2) further validates Fe-induced lattice disorder [46,47]. To validate the reconstruction process, we performed XANES analysis on the Ni and Fe K-edges of PSF-0.75-Ni before and after the OER test to probe the oxidation states of Ni and Fe. As illustrated in Fig. 5(h), the Ni K-edge XANES spectra of the post-OER sample exhibit a shift of the absorption edge peak positions to higher energies compared with those of the initial sample, indicating an increase in the valence state of Ni. Furthermore, Fourier transform (FT) k 3-weighted extended XAFS (EXAFS) spectra reveal a decrease in the Ni–O bond length of PSF-0.75-Ni from the initial 1.63 to 1.6 Å after OER (Fig. 5i). This shortening of the bond length further confirms the transition of Ni to a higher valence state with a smaller ionic radius. Similarly, the Fe K-edge XANES spectra and their corresponding FT-EXAFS profiles demonstrate that Fe in the post-OER PSF-0.75-Ni also undergoes oxidation to a higher valence state, as evidenced by a decrease in the Fe–O bond length from 1.5 to 1.47 Å (Fig. 5h, i). Meanwhile, the XPS spectra of the PSF-0.75-Ni sample after OER testing (Fig. S44) reveal 0.6 and 0.5 eV positive shifts in Ni 2p 3/2 and Fe 2p 3/2 binding energies, respectively, corresponding to increased Ni3+/(Ni2++Ni3+) (from 33% to 45%) and Fe3+/(Fe2++Fe3+) (from 48% to 67%) ratios, further confirming the in-situ generation of the NiFeOOH active phase. The O 1s spectrum shows that the content of high oxidation state oxygen species (O−/O2 −) increases from 17.3% to 19.4%, indicating the generation of more oxygen defects during the OER process. Stability tests (Fig. S44) demonstrate that after 1000 CV cycles, the surface vibrational features of PSF-0.75-Ni remain largely unchanged compared to its initial state, confirming the excellent structural stability of the amorphous/crystalline heterostructure. 2.4 Theoretical analysis To elucidate the atomic-scale dynamics of perovskite@hydroxide core-shell structure formation in NiCl2 solution, we conducted AIMD simulations with a 0.5 fs timestep over 25 ps (Supplementary Video S1 and S2) [48,49]. The theoretical model incorporates a Ni2+ ion and two Cl− ions in a 1 g cm−3 water matrix to replicate the weakly acidic NiCl2 environment [50]. Fig. 6 (a–d) revealed that water molecules were preferentially adsorbed onto surface Sr2+ sites, where they dissociated in the region between Ni2+ and Sr2+. The OH− species generated from water dissociation around Ni2+ formed Ni(OH)2 precursors through coordination rearrangement, while protons attacked the oxygen atoms adjacent to Sr2+, leading to the formation of oxygen vacancies. These vacancies further facilitated the dissolution of A-site Sr2+ and B-site Fe3+, with the dissolved Fe3+ participating in the self-assembly of the amorphous NiFe LDH shell. Notably, the significant difference in formation energy of A-site cation vacancies between Pr3+ (7.52 eV in Pr0.25Sr0.75FeO3 model) and Sr2+ (−5.11 eV in SrFeO3 model and 5.91 eV in Pr0.25Sr0.75FeO3 model) confirms the pronounced anchoring effect of the rare earth Pr element on the stability of the perovskite framework (Figs. S45, S46) [51]. Based on AIMD simulations, we constructed a reaction pathway for H+ ion migration from positions over Sr2+ ions to nearby coordinating oxygen atoms, coupled with oxygen vacancy formation (Fig. S46). This process occurs concomitantly with water hydrolysis between Ni2+ and Sr2+. As shown in Fig. S47, the transition state barrier for this process in Pr0.25Sr0.75FeO3 is 0.41 eV, significantly higher than that in SrFeO3 (0.04 eV). This higher barrier implies a slower reaction rate for perovskite oxide etching in the presence of Pr3+ ions. Previous references indicate that Pourbaix diagrams are instrumental in assessing the thermodynamic stability of materials in solution. Based on Pourbaix diagrams calculated via the Materials Project (Figs. S48, S49), Sr2+ ions in SrFeO3 have higher solubility over a wider pH range compared to Pr3+ in PrFeO3. This observation further underscores the critical role of Pr3+ ions in enhancing perovskite stability. To decipher the function of amorphous hydroxides observed via operando Raman spectroscopy, we established comparative NiOOH and NiFeOOH models (Fig. S50). Structural analysis (Fig. 6e) revealed that Fe3+ doping caused stretching of the Ni–O6 octahedral bond lengths (Δd = 0.01 Å), inducing lattice distortions and increasing structural disorder. Density of states (DOS) calculations (Fig. 6g) showed that NiFeOOH exhibited significantly enhanced electronic density near the Fermi level, with greater hybridization compared to NiOOH, indicating that Fe doping effectively promotes interfacial charge transfer. Notably, compared to NiOOH (2.14 eV), the metal d-orbital center of NiFeOOH (1.79 eV) shifts 0.35 eV in the positive direction. Crystal field theory analysis indicates that the introduction of Fe3+ induces d-orbital reordering of Ni; specifically, the dx 2 − y 2 orbital of Ni shifts toward the Fermi level by 0.06 eV, which facilitates the adsorption of OER intermediates (Fig. S51) [52,53]. Gibbs free energy calculations reveal that NiOOH exhibits a notably higher activation barrier of 0.90 eV in the OH* deprotonation step to O*. In contrast, NiFeOOH achieves a significant reduction in this activation barrier to 0.26 eV due to the positive shift of the Ni d-orbital center, which enhances the O* adsorption energy. This outperforms both Fe sites in NiFeOOH (0.42 eV) and pristine PSF-0.75 (0.58 eV), establishing Ni as the dominant active center. The bonding characteristics of the Ni–O* bond during the OER process were further quantitatively analyzed using crystal orbital Hamilton population (COHP) (Fig. 6i, j). Compared to the 1.86 of NiOOH, the −COHP value of the Ni–O* bond in NiFeOOH is higher than 1.93, further demonstrating that Fe ion doping provides stronger adsorption capability for Ni sites [53–55]. Our theoretical calculations reveal the in-situ formation of an amorphous shell and Fe doping in the NiO6 configuration significantly strengthen O* adsorption at the Ni active site, thus lowering the rate-determining step barrier and enhancing OER activity. Given that core-shell structured materials exhibit enhanced catalytic activity compared to simple hydroxides, we calculated the charge density difference and DOS for the PSF-0.75/NiFeOOH heterostructure to elucidate the contribution of perovskite oxides to OER catalysis. As shown in Fig. S52, electrons are transferred from Fe3+ in the perovskite oxide to the oxyhydroxide. Compared to pristine NiFeOOH (O 2p band center = −3.25 eV), PSF-0.75/NiFeOOH (O 2p band center = −2.81 eV) exhibits an increased electron density near the Fermi level, with its O 2p band center shifting closer to the Fermi energy. This would enhance the orbital hybridisation of oxygen atoms with OER intermediates on the catalyst surface. This may be one of the key reasons why the heterogeneous structure exhibits higher catalytic activity compared to a single NiFe LDH. 2.5 Zn-air batteries To systematically evaluate the enhancing role of the amorphous/crystalline core-shell structure in the bifunctional catalytic performance of perovskite oxides, this study constructed a liquid ZAB system using PSF-0.75-Ni and PSF-0.75 as cathode catalysts. Fig. 7 (b) revealed that the PSF-0.75-Ni-based ZABs exhibited a higher open-circuit voltage compared to the PSF-0.75-based ZABs. LSV curves reveal that PSF-0.75-Ni exhibits significantly lower voltage differences between charge and discharge at various current densities compared to the PSF-0.75-based battery, particularly a substantial reduction in charging voltage. Meanwhile, the PSF-0.75-Ni catalyst achieved a peak power density of 92.9 mW cm−2, representing a 41.1% improvement over the PSF-0.75 baseline (65.8 mW cm−2). The ZABs utilizing PSF-0.75-Ni as a catalyst maintained a more stable discharge platform across a wide current density range (5–50 mA cm−2) than using PSF-0.75. When subjected to constant current discharge (Fig. 7f), ZABs with PSF-0.75-Ni as the catalyst consistently demonstrated higher discharge voltage and energy density compared to those with PSF-0.75. As shown in Fig. 7(g), the stability of different catalysts was evaluated through a 30-min discharge/30-min charge cycling period. Compared to the 58% efficiency of PSF-0.75, ZABs utilized PSF-0.75-Ni as a catalyst, achieving an initial energy conversion efficiency of 63%. After 300 h of continuous operation, the voltage difference remained minimal, increasing only by 0.12 V (from 0.71 to 0.83 V), significantly outperforming the commercial Pt/C-RuO2 catalysts (ΔV = 0.213 V). Particularly, the charge cut-off voltage of ZABs with PSF-0.75-Ni as the catalyst increased by only about 0.004 V after 300 h of cycling tests, significantly lower than the 0.03 V increase for Pt/C+RuO2, further demonstrating its excellent OER stability. For comparison, a battery using PSF-0.75 as the catalyst only maintained a cycling life of less than 200 h. The enhanced cycle stability can be attributed to the protective role of the amorphous hydroxide shell, which inhibited the dissolution and loss of active components from the perovskite core and improved the working environment of the catalyst through hetero-interface interactions. 3 Conclusions In summary, this work establishes a universal selective etching strategy for constructing crystalline@amorphous hydroxide heterostructures, with combined experimental and theoretical investigations elucidating the dynamic coupling mechanisms of A-site cation dissolution, oxygen vacancy generation, and amorphous shell growth during core-shell reconstruction. The optimized Pr0.25Sr0.75FeO3− δ @NiFe LDH catalyst demonstrates a 212 mV reduction in ORR/OER bifunctional voltage gap compared to pristine perovskite. When implemented as air cathodes in ZABs, the catalyst delivers enhanced performance metrics: a peak power density of 92.9 mW cm−2 and minimal energy efficiency decay (6.3%) during charge-discharge cycling of 300 h, significantly outperforming commercial Pt/C-RuO2 systems (10.2% efficiency loss). These breakthroughs stem from the synergistic integration of perovskite-stabilized ORR pathways and amorphous shell-enhanced OER kinetics, providing both theoretical insights and practical solutions for high-performance electrode design of the metal-air battery. coredata.dc:description: The bifunctional oxygen evolution/reduction reaction (OER/ORR) performance of perovskite oxides in zinc-air batteries (ZABs) is fundamentally constrained by the unidirectional catalytic activity of B-site transition metal elements. This work proposes a heterostructure engineering strategy through selective etching to construct crystalline perovskite@amorphous hydroxide composites with spatially segregated active sites, where crystalline cores are for ORR and amorphous shells are for OER. Our investigation reveals that the differential solubility of alkaline-earth and rare-earth elements in acidic media enables precise control over surface amorphous layer composition and thickness through A-site cation ratio modulation and tailored etching protocols. Ab initio molecular dynamics (AIMD) simulations reveal the coupled process of A-site cations dissolution, oxygen vacancy formation, and amorphous-layer growth during the dynamic restructuring of the core-shell structure. The optimized Pr0.25Sr0.75FeO3− δ @NiFe LDH achieved a 212 mV improvement of OER/ORR potential gap (ΔE = E 10 mA cm−2 − E 1/2) over pristine Pr0.25Sr0.75FeO3− δ . When deployed in ZABs, the catalyst demonstrates a peak power density of 92.9 mW cm−2 and exceptional cycling stability with only 6.3% energy efficiency decay after 300 h (vs. 10.2% decay for Pt/C-RuO2). This work establishes a universal “composition-guided reconstruction” paradigm, providing both theoretical insights and practical solutions for high-performance electrode design of ZABs.
